Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts
Definition: Condition where limited resources cannot satisfy unlimited wants, forcing choices about what to produce, how, and for whom
Example: Time, land, and capital are limited so not all goods and services can be produced
CLEP Trap: Often confused with a temporary shortage; scarcity is permanent and universal, shortages are temporary market outcomes

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts
Definition: Value of the next best alternative forgone when a choice is made
Example: Choosing to study for two hours instead of working; opportunity cost is the wages you could have earned
CLEP Trap: Students list all alternatives as 'cost'; only the single highest-valued foregone option counts

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts
Definition: Situation where gaining more of one thing requires giving up something else due to scarcity
Example: Allocating more land to housing means less land for parks
CLEP Trap: Students treat trade-offs as only money-related, ignoring time and resource trade-offs

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts
Definition: Decision-making approach that compares the additional benefit of one more unit to the additional cost
Example: A firm hires another worker only if the extra revenue exceeds the extra wage cost
CLEP Trap: Students use total or average values instead of marginal values when applying decision rules
Related Formula/Relationship: Optimal when marginal benefit = marginal cost

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts
Definition: Curve showing maximum combinations of two goods that can be produced with available resources and technology
Example: Trade-off between producing robots and pizzas at full employment
CLEP Trap: Points inside PPC are attainable but inefficient; points outside are unattainable with current resources

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts
Definition: Increase in an economy's capacity to produce, represented by an outward shift of the PPC
Example: Improved technology in both agriculture and manufacturing shifts the frontier outward
CLEP Trap: Moving along an existing PPC is not growth, it is just reallocating production

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts
Definition: Ability to produce more of a good with the same amount of resources than another producer
Example: Country A can produce 10 units of wheat while Country B can produce 6 with same resources
CLEP Trap: Students incorrectly use absolute advantage to determine specialization instead of comparative advantage

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts
Definition: Ability to produce a good at a lower opportunity cost than another producer, which determines specialization and trade
Example: If Country A gives up 2 cloth per wheat and Country B gives up 4 cloth per wheat, A has comparative advantage in wheat
CLEP Trap: Students pick the producer who makes the most output instead of lowest opportunity cost

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts
Definition: Agreed exchange ratio between goods that allows both trading partners to gain from trade
Example: If A trades 1 wheat for between 2 and 4 cloth, both A and B benefit
CLEP Trap: Choosing trade ratios outside the range between opportunity costs benefits only one country or neither
Related Formula/Relationship: Must lie between each country's opportunity cost for that good

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts
Definition: Ceteris paribus, as the price of a good falls, the quantity demanded rises; as price rises, quantity demanded falls
Example: Lower movie ticket prices lead more people to buy tickets
CLEP Trap: Confusing a 'change in demand' (shift) with 'change in quantity demanded' (movement along curve)
Related Formula/Relationship: Inverse relationship between price and quantity demanded

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts
Definition: Ceteris paribus, as the price of a good rises, the quantity supplied rises; as price falls, quantity supplied falls
Example: Higher apple prices encourage farmers to supply more apples
CLEP Trap: Students call a movement up the supply curve an 'increase in supply' when only price changed
Related Formula/Relationship: Direct relationship between price and quantity supplied

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts
Definition: Price and quantity where quantity demanded equals quantity supplied, with no inherent pressure to change
Example: At $5 per unit, buyers want 100 units and sellers supply 100 units
CLEP Trap: Students interpret equilibrium as 'fair' or 'socially optimal'; it simply balances Qd and Qs

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts
Definition: Quantity demanded exceeds quantity supplied at a price below equilibrium
Example: At $3 when equilibrium is $5, more consumers want the good than producers are willing to supply
CLEP Trap: Students label any high price as shortage instead of comparing Qd vs Qs

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts
Definition: Quantity supplied exceeds quantity demanded at a price above equilibrium
Example: At $7 when equilibrium is $5, sellers can't sell all they produce
CLEP Trap: Students mislabel surplus as shortage when they focus only on price level, not quantities

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts
Definition: Legal maximum price; if set below equilibrium, it is binding and creates a shortage
Example: Rent control capping rent below market rate
CLEP Trap: Students confuse which policy causes shortage; binding ceiling creates shortage, not surplus

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts
Definition: Legal minimum price; if set above equilibrium, it is binding and creates a surplus
Example: Minimum wage set above market wage causing excess labor supply
CLEP Trap: Students incorrectly say floors cause shortages; binding floors cause surpluses

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts
Definition: Good for which demand increases when income increases, holding other factors constant
Example: Restaurant meals demanded more as consumer income rises
CLEP Trap: Students confuse normal goods with 'luxury' goods only; normal includes many everyday items

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts
Definition: Good for which demand decreases when income increases, holding other factors constant
Example: Instant noodles may be consumed less as income rises
CLEP Trap: Students confuse 'inferior' with low quality; it is about income response, not quality

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts
Definition: Goods that can replace each other in consumption; when price of one rises, demand for the other rises
Example: Tea and coffee; if coffee price rises, demand for tea increases
CLEP Trap: Students mix up substitutes and complements, reversing demand shift directions

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts
Definition: Goods consumed together; when price of one rises, demand for the other falls
Example: Cars and gasoline; higher gas prices reduce demand for cars
CLEP Trap: Students misidentify complements as substitutes and predict wrong demand change

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Supply and Demand
Definition: Definition
Example: Example
CLEP Trap: CLEP Trap

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Supply and Demand
Definition: Non-price factors that shift the entire demand curve: income, tastes, prices of related goods, expectations, number of buyers
Example: Increase in population shifts demand for housing rightward
CLEP Trap: Students treat a change in the good's own price as a shifter instead of a movement along demand

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Supply and Demand
Definition: Non-price factors that shift the entire supply curve: input prices, technology, taxes/subsidies, expectations, number of sellers
Example: Technological improvement lowers production cost and shifts supply to the right
CLEP Trap: Students confuse cost changes with demand shifts when the underlying shock is clearly cost-side

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Supply and Demand
Definition: Measure of responsiveness of quantity demanded to a change in price
Example: Demand for movie tickets falls sharply when ticket prices rise modestly
CLEP Trap: Reversing formula and computing (%ΔP / %ΔQ) instead of (%ΔQ / %ΔP)
Related Formula/Relationship: Ed = (% change in quantity demanded) / (% change in price)

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Supply and Demand
Definition: Demand where the absolute value of elasticity is greater than 1; quantity responds strongly to price changes
Example: A 10 percent price drop increases quantity demanded by 25 percent
CLEP Trap: Students assume steep curves are always more inelastic without calculating percentage changes

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Supply and Demand
Definition: Demand where the absolute value of elasticity is less than 1; quantity responds weakly to price changes
Example: Gasoline demand changes little when price increases
CLEP Trap: Students misapply total revenue rules because they misjudge elasticity type

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Supply and Demand
Definition: Demand where the absolute value of elasticity equals 1; percentage change in quantity equals percentage change in price
Example: A 10 percent price increase causes a 10 percent drop in quantity demanded
CLEP Trap: Forgetting that total revenue is maximized at unit elasticity on a straight-line demand curve

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Supply and Demand
Definition: Total amount received by sellers, equal to price times quantity sold
Example: A firm selling 100 units at $5 earns $500 in total revenue
CLEP Trap: Students confuse TR with profit (profit subtracts total cost)

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Supply and Demand
Definition: With elastic demand, price and total revenue move in opposite directions; with inelastic demand, they move in same direction
Example: Raising price with inelastic demand (like insulin) increases total revenue
CLEP Trap: Students memorize rules but apply them backward under pressure
Related Formula/Relationship: Elastic: P↑ → TR↓; Inelastic: P↑ → TR↑

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Supply and Demand
Definition: Difference between what consumers are willing to pay and what they actually pay; area under demand curve above price
Example: If a buyer is willing to pay $10 but pays $7, consumer surplus is $3
CLEP Trap: Students shade area above demand or below price incorrectly, mixing it with producer surplus
Related Formula/Relationship: Area under demand curve and above price line up to quantity

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Supply and Demand
Definition: Difference between actual price received and the minimum price producers are willing to accept; area above supply curve below price
Example: A seller willing to accept $4 but sells for $7 gains $3 in producer surplus
CLEP Trap: Students treat producer surplus as equal to profit; profit subtracts total cost, not just marginal willingness
Related Formula/Relationship: Area above supply curve and below price line up to quantity

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Supply and Demand
Definition: Loss of total surplus when quantity traded is below the efficient equilibrium due to taxes, price controls, or market power
Example: Tax on a good reducing quantity traded from Q* to Qt creates a DWL triangle
CLEP Trap: Students shade the entire tax rectangle as DWL instead of the smaller lost-trade triangle
Related Formula/Relationship: Area of triangle between supply and demand from Q* to Qt

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Supply and Demand
Definition: Division of the economic burden of a tax between buyers and sellers, determined by relative elasticities
Example: If demand is inelastic and supply elastic, consumers bear more of the tax
CLEP Trap: Students think who 'legally' sends the tax determines incidence; it's actually elasticity that matters
Related Formula/Relationship: More inelastic side bears more of the burden

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Supply and Demand
Definition: Binding ceilings and floors create inefficiency by preventing the market from reaching equilibrium quantity, generating DWL
Example: Rent control reduces quantity of apartments supplied and quality, causing DWL
CLEP Trap: Forgetting that even if some consumers pay less, total surplus is lower

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Consumer Choice
Definition: Definition
Example: Example
CLEP Trap: CLEP Trap

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Consumer Choice
Definition: Total satisfaction derived from consuming a given quantity of a good or service
Example: Total satisfaction from eating three slices of pizza
CLEP Trap: Students think TU must decrease as quantity increases; TU usually rises while MU falls

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Consumer Choice
Definition: Additional satisfaction from consuming one more unit of a good or service
Example: Extra satisfaction from eating a fourth slice of pizza
CLEP Trap: Confusing MU with TU; exam questions often give MU tables, not TU
Related Formula/Relationship: MU = change in total utility / change in quantity

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Consumer Choice
Definition: Principle that marginal utility decreases as more units of a good are consumed
Example: First slice of pizza gives high MU; by the fourth slice, MU is much lower
CLEP Trap: Students assume TU must fall when MU falls; TU still rises while MU is positive

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Consumer Choice
Definition: Consumers maximize total utility when marginal utility per dollar is equal across all goods and the budget is fully spent
Example: Choosing quantities of pizza and soda so MU(pizza)/P(pizza) = MU(soda)/P(soda)
CLEP Trap: Students incorrectly set MU of goods equal without dividing by price

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Consumer Choice
Definition: Line showing all combinations of two goods a consumer can afford given income and prices
Example: With $20, pizzas at $10 and sodas at $2, budget line shows combinations of pizzas and sodas
CLEP Trap: Misreading a pivot of the budget line as income change rather than price change

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Consumer Choice
Definition: Change in quantity demanded resulting from a change in real purchasing power when the price of a good changes
Example: Fall in price of a normal good effectively makes consumer richer, increasing quantity demanded
CLEP Trap: Students attribute all quantity change to substitution effect and ignore income effect

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Consumer Choice
Definition: Change in quantity demanded because a good becomes relatively cheaper or more expensive compared to alternatives
Example: If pizza becomes cheaper relative to burgers, consumers substitute pizza for burgers
CLEP Trap: Confusing substitution effect with shift of demand curve rather than movement along it

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Consumer Choice
Definition: Normal goods see increased consumption when income rises; inferior goods see decreased consumption when income rises
Example: More restaurant meals (normal), fewer instant noodles (inferior) as income rises
CLEP Trap: Students label low-quality goods as inferior without considering income response

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Production and Costs
Definition: Definition
Example: Example
CLEP Trap: CLEP Trap

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Production and Costs
Definition: Short run: at least one input is fixed; long run: all inputs are variable
Example: A factory size fixed this year (short run) but can be expanded over several years (long run)
CLEP Trap: Students define short and long run by calendar time rather than fixed vs variable inputs

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Production and Costs
Definition: Total quantity of output produced with a given amount of inputs
Example: A farm's total bushels of wheat harvested from its land and labor
CLEP Trap: Confusing TP with average or marginal product when reading tables

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Production and Costs
Definition: Additional output produced by using one more unit of a variable input, holding other inputs constant
Example: Extra output from hiring one more worker
CLEP Trap: Using change in input divided by change in output instead of the reverse
Related Formula/Relationship: MP = change in TP / change in input

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Production and Costs
Definition: Output per unit of input
Example: If 5 workers produce 100 units, AP of labor is 20 units per worker
CLEP Trap: Students mix AP and MP when determining where diminishing returns begin

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Production and Costs
Definition: As more units of a variable input are added to fixed inputs, marginal product eventually decreases
Example: Adding more workers to a fixed-size kitchen eventually makes each extra worker less productive
CLEP Trap: Students think the law applies immediately; MP often rises at first, then falls

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Production and Costs
Definition: Cost that does not vary with output in the short run
Example: Monthly rent for a factory building
CLEP Trap: Treating labor costs as fixed when they are usually variable

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Production and Costs
Definition: Cost that varies with level of output
Example: Wages for hourly workers and cost of raw materials
CLEP Trap: Including long-term lease payments as variable cost; these are fixed in short run

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Production and Costs
Definition: Sum of fixed and variable costs at each output level
Example: If FC is $100 and VC is $300, TC is $400
CLEP Trap: Forgetting TC includes both fixed and variable components

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Production and Costs
Definition: Total cost per unit of output
Example: If TC is $400 and Q is 50, ATC is $8
CLEP Trap: Students confuse ATC with AVC or miscalculate by ignoring FC

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Production and Costs
Definition: Variable cost per unit of output
Example: If VC is $300 and Q is 50, AVC is $6
CLEP Trap: Using TC in place of VC in the numerator

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Production and Costs
Definition: Fixed cost per unit of output
Example: If FC is $100 and Q is 50, AFC is $2
CLEP Trap: Expecting AFC to be U-shaped; it always declines as Q increases

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Production and Costs
Definition: Additional cost of producing one more unit of output
Example: If TC rises from $400 to $420 when output increases from 50 to 55, MC is $4
CLEP Trap: Using average cost instead of change in TC when computing MC
Related Formula/Relationship: MC = change in TC / change in Q

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Production and Costs
Definition: MC intersects both ATC and AVC at their minimum points; when MC < ATC, ATC falls, when MC > ATC, ATC rises
Example: At low output, adding units reduces ATC; after minimum ATC, additional units raise ATC
CLEP Trap: Mislabeling curves so MC does not intersect at minimum points, leading to misinterpretation

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Production and Costs
Definition: Firm should continue producing in short run if price ≥ AVC, and shut down if price < AVC
Example: If price covers variable costs but not fixed costs, firm still produces to minimize losses
CLEP Trap: Students use ATC instead of AVC to determine shutdown point

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Production and Costs
Definition: Long-run situation where increasing output lowers long-run average total cost
Example: A large factory can produce at lower ATC than a small workshop due to specialization
CLEP Trap: Students confuse this with diminishing marginal returns, which is a short-run concept

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Production and Costs
Definition: Long-run situation where increasing output raises long-run average total cost
Example: Very large firms suffering from coordination and bureaucracy problems
CLEP Trap: Attributing rising ATC purely to diminishing marginal returns instead of scale issues

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Firm Behavior and Market Structure
Definition: Definition
Example: Example
CLEP Trap: CLEP Trap

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Firm Behavior and Market Structure
Definition: Total income a firm receives from selling its output
Example: Selling 100 units at $5 yields TR of $500
CLEP Trap: Students treat TR as profit without subtracting total cost

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Firm Behavior and Market Structure
Definition: Additional revenue from selling one more unit of output
Example: TR rises from $500 to $520 when selling one more unit, MR = $20
CLEP Trap: Students use total revenue or average revenue instead of marginal change
Related Formula/Relationship: MR = change in TR / change in Q

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Firm Behavior and Market Structure
Definition: Firm's total revenue minus all explicit and implicit costs
Example: Entrepreneur earns revenue of $200k, explicit costs of $150k, implicit costs of $30k, economic profit = $20k
CLEP Trap: Students think zero economic profit is failure; it means firm is covering opportunity costs

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Firm Behavior and Market Structure
Definition: Total revenue minus only explicit costs
Example: Same firm above has accounting profit of $50k while economic profit is $20k
CLEP Trap: Students confuse accounting profit with economic profit when interpreting 'normal' returns

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Firm Behavior and Market Structure
Definition: Zero economic profit; situation where firm earns just enough to cover all costs including opportunity costs
Example: Competitive firm in long-run equilibrium earns normal profit
CLEP Trap: Students equate zero economic profit to bankruptcy; actually, firm is doing as well as alternatives

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Firm Behavior and Market Structure
Definition: Any firm maximizes profit by producing output where marginal revenue equals marginal cost
Example: Choosing Q where MR and MC curves intersect
CLEP Trap: Students incorrectly use 'produce where ATC is minimized' or where TR is highest without MR = MC check

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Firm Behavior and Market Structure
Definition: Market with many small firms, identical products, free entry/exit, and price-taking firms
Example: Wheat farming with many small producers selling homogeneous output
CLEP Trap: Students draw downward-sloping demand for individual firm; firm actually faces a horizontal demand at market price
Related Formula/Relationship: Firm's demand is perfectly elastic at market price

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Firm Behavior and Market Structure
Definition: Firm chooses output where P = MR = MC; may earn profits, losses, or break even
Example: If price is above ATC at Q where MR = MC, firm earns economic profit
CLEP Trap: Students ignore shutdown rule and assume firm should always produce when P < ATC
Related Formula/Relationship: Produce if P ≥ AVC; shut down if P < AVC

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Firm Behavior and Market Structure
Definition: Entry and exit drive economic profits to zero; firms produce at minimum ATC and P = MC = ATC
Example: New firms enter industry when profits exist, shifting supply until profit disappears
CLEP Trap: Students think competitive firms can maintain economic profits indefinitely despite free entry
Related Formula/Relationship: Long-run: P = minimum ATC and P = MC

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Firm Behavior and Market Structure
Definition: Market with one firm, unique product, high barriers to entry, and price-making ability
Example: Local water utility with exclusive franchise
CLEP Trap: Students confuse monopoly with monopolistic competition (many firms, differentiated products)

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Firm Behavior and Market Structure
Definition: Monopolist faces the market demand curve; marginal revenue lies below demand because lowering price affects all units sold
Example: To sell more units, a monopolist must cut price, so MR < price
CLEP Trap: Students draw MR equal to demand as in perfect competition
Related Formula/Relationship: MR curve lies below demand curve

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Firm Behavior and Market Structure
Definition: Monopolist produces at quantity where MR = MC and charges the price on demand curve at that quantity
Example: Choosing Q where MR and MC intersect, then using demand curve to find P
CLEP Trap: Students mistakenly set P equal to MC or ATC to find monopoly price
Related Formula/Relationship: Choose Q where MR = MC, then price from demand at that Q

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Firm Behavior and Market Structure
Definition: Monopoly restricts output below competitive level and charges higher price, causing deadweight loss
Example: Competitive output Qc at P = MC vs monopoly output Qm with Pm > MC
CLEP Trap: Students think monopoly just 'earns more profit' but ignore lost surplus from reduced trades

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Firm Behavior and Market Structure
Definition: Charging different prices to different consumers for the same good based on willingness to pay, not cost
Example: Student discounts at movie theaters or airline ticket pricing
CLEP Trap: Students confuse legal discrimination (discounts) with illegal; exam focuses on economics, not law

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Firm Behavior and Market Structure
Definition: Monopolist charges each consumer their maximum willingness to pay, capturing all consumer surplus
Example: Charging each unit at a unique price based on buyer's valuation
CLEP Trap: Students think it increases deadweight loss; in the model, it removes DWL but shifts surplus to firm
Related Formula/Relationship: Eliminates DWL; total surplus stays same but is all producer surplus

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Firm Behavior and Market Structure
Definition: Market with many firms selling differentiated products and free entry/exit
Example: Restaurants in a city offering different cuisines and styles
CLEP Trap: Students call any firm with market power a monopoly; here, many firms exist and entry is easy

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Firm Behavior and Market Structure
Definition: Entry and exit drive economic profit to zero; each firm faces downward-sloping demand tangent to ATC at profit-maximizing output
Example: Demand curve just touches ATC at Q where MR = MC
CLEP Trap: Students assume long-run production occurs at minimum ATC; in fact, there is excess capacity
Related Formula/Relationship: Long-run: zero economic profit but P > MC and not at min ATC

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Firm Behavior and Market Structure
Definition: Firm produces less than the output level that minimizes ATC in the long run
Example: A coffee shop could lower ATC by serving more customers but demand isn't high enough
CLEP Trap: Students think zero economic profit implies fully efficient production at minimum ATC
Related Formula/Relationship: Actual Q < Q at minimum ATC

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Firm Behavior and Market Structure
Definition: Market with few large firms, barriers to entry, and strategic interdependence
Example: Airline industry with few major carriers
CLEP Trap: Students treat oligopoly like perfect competition or monopoly without considering strategic behavior

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Firm Behavior and Market Structure
Definition: Framework to analyze strategic interactions where payoff depends on own and rivals' choices
Example: Two firms choosing high or low prices with payoffs shown in a matrix
CLEP Trap: Students select highest joint payoff instead of checking for Nash equilibrium stability

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 2 Product Markets – Firm Behavior and Market Structure
Definition: Outcome where no player can gain by unilaterally changing strategy given others' strategies
Example: Both firms choose 'high price' if deviation alone would lower their payoff
CLEP Trap: Students think Nash outcome must maximize total industry profit; it need not

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 Factor Markets
Definition: Definition
Example: Example
CLEP Trap: CLEP Trap

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 Factor Markets
Definition: Demand for labor that arises from demand for the goods and services labor helps produce
Example: Higher demand for cars increases demand for auto workers
CLEP Trap: Students treat labor demand as independent of product market conditions

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 Factor Markets
Definition: Additional revenue a firm earns by employing one more unit of a factor of production
Example: If one more worker produces 5 units and each sells for $10, MRP = $50
CLEP Trap: Students forget to multiply marginal product by price or MR when computing MRP
Related Formula/Relationship: MRP = MP × MR (in perfect competition, MP × price)

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 Factor Markets
Definition: Additional cost of hiring one more unit of a factor
Example: In a competitive labor market, MFC equals the wage rate
CLEP Trap: Students use average wage instead of marginal cost when applying hiring rule
Related Formula/Relationship: In competitive labor market, MFC = wage

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 Factor Markets
Definition: Profit-maximizing firm hires labor up to the point where marginal revenue product equals marginal factor cost
Example: Firm hires workers until MRP = wage
CLEP Trap: Students keep hiring as long as MRP is positive instead of comparing to wage

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 Factor Markets
Definition: Downward-sloping curve showing quantity of labor firms hire at each wage, equal to MRP curve
Example: Lower wage increases quantity of labor demanded by firms
CLEP Trap: Students confuse individual firm’s labor demand with market labor demand but shape is same (downward-sloping)

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 Factor Markets
Definition: Upward-sloping curve showing quantity of labor workers supply at each wage (market level)
Example: Higher wage induces more workers to enter the labor force or work more hours
CLEP Trap: Students draw firm's labor supply as upward sloping; for competitive firm, supply is horizontal at market wage

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 Factor Markets
Definition: Wage and employment level where market labor supply equals market labor demand
Example: At $20 per hour, firms demand and workers supply 10,000 labor hours
CLEP Trap: Students think an individual firm can affect wage; competitive firms are wage takers

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 Factor Markets
Definition: Changes in product demand, worker productivity, or prices of other inputs shift labor demand
Example: New technology increases labor productivity, shifting labor demand right
CLEP Trap: Students ignore effect of output demand on derived labor demand

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 Factor Markets
Definition: Changes in population, preferences for work vs leisure, or alternative opportunities shift labor supply
Example: Increase in working-age population shifts labor supply right
CLEP Trap: Students mix up demand and supply shifters when wages change

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 Factor Markets
Definition: Single or dominant buyer of labor facing an upward-sloping labor supply, resulting in wage-setting power below competitive level
Example: Company town with one major employer
CLEP Trap: Students apply competitive labor market logic (wage = MRP) instead of monopsony condition
Related Formula/Relationship: Monopsony hires where MRP = MFC, pays lower wage from supply curve

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 4 Market Failure and Role of Government
Definition: Definition
Example: Example
CLEP Trap: CLEP Trap

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 4 Market Failure and Role of Government
Definition: Spillover cost imposed on third parties not reflected in market transactions, leading to overproduction
Example: Pollution from a factory harming nearby residents' health
CLEP Trap: Students shift demand instead of supply when externality is due to production costs
Related Formula/Relationship: MSC > MPC; market Q > socially optimal Q

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 4 Market Failure and Role of Government
Definition: Spillover benefit received by third parties not reflected in market transactions, leading to underproduction
Example: Vaccination providing herd immunity benefits to others
CLEP Trap: Students move supply when external benefit affects consumption (demand side)
Related Formula/Relationship: MSB > MPB; market Q < socially optimal Q

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 4 Market Failure and Role of Government
Definition: Output level where marginal social benefit equals marginal social cost, internalizing externalities
Example: Setting pollution tax so that firms reduce emissions to Q* where MSC = MSB
CLEP Trap: Students confuse private equilibrium (MPB = MPC) with social optimum (MSB = MSC)

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 4 Market Failure and Role of Government
Definition: Tax imposed on a good with negative externalities equal to marginal external cost to correct overproduction
Example: Per-unit pollution tax that aligns private and social costs
CLEP Trap: Assuming any tax is Pigouvian; it must be calibrated to external cost to hit social optimum
Related Formula/Relationship: Tax set so MPC + tax = MSC at Q*

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 4 Market Failure and Role of Government
Definition: Subsidy on goods with positive externalities equal to marginal external benefit to correct underproduction
Example: Subsidy for education encouraging more schooling to socially optimal level
CLEP Trap: Students confuse generic subsidies (price supports) with targeted externality subsidies
Related Formula/Relationship: Subsidy set so MPB + subsidy = MSB at Q*

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 4 Market Failure and Role of Government
Definition: Good that is nonrival and nonexcludable, meaning one person's use doesn't reduce availability and non-payers can't be easily excluded
Example: National defense protecting all residents in a country
CLEP Trap: Students label any government-provided good as public good even when it is rival or excludable

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 4 Market Failure and Role of Government
Definition: Situation where people benefit from a good without paying, leading to underprovision by private markets
Example: People enjoying public fireworks without contributing to costs
CLEP Trap: Students apply free-rider logic to private, excludable goods, where firms can charge users

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 4 Market Failure and Role of Government
Definition: Good that is rival but nonexcludable, prone to overuse and depletion
Example: Open-access fishery where anyone can fish and catches diminish
CLEP Trap: Students confuse common resources with public goods; commons are rival and get overused

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 4 Market Failure and Role of Government
Definition: Overuse of a common resource because individuals ignore the external cost of their use on others
Example: Overgrazing on common pasture land until grass is depleted
CLEP Trap: Students attribute overuse to high prices rather than lack of property rights or exclusion

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 4 Market Failure and Role of Government
Definition: Good that is nonrival but excludable, often provided by private firms with membership or fees
Example: Streaming service where additional users do not reduce others' enjoyment but access is restricted
CLEP Trap: Students lump club goods with public goods or private goods without checking rivalry and excludability

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 4 Market Failure and Role of Government
Definition: Government laws and actions to promote competition and prevent monopolies and collusive behavior
Example: Breaking up a dominant firm or preventing anti-competitive mergers
CLEP Trap: Students assume antitrust always lowers prices; some natural monopolies might need regulation rather than breakup

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 4 Market Failure and Role of Government
Definition: Government setting prices for a single-firm industry with declining ATC over relevant range to prevent excessive pricing
Example: Utility regulator sets price = ATC so firm covers costs but earns zero economic profit
CLEP Trap: Students think price must always be set equal to MC, which could cause losses in natural monopoly
Related Formula/Relationship: Regulated price often P = ATC for zero economic profit
